column2: ENGLISH
The Church of Saint Peter
The church founded in Antioch by the apostle Peter. One of the oldest churches in Christendom.
Hagia Sophia
Traditional seat of the Patriarch of Constantinople, commissioned in 532 CE by the Roman Emperor Justinian I and originally finished in 537 CE.
Church of the Holy Sepulchre
The church containing two of the holiest sites in Christianity, the site of the Crucifixion and the site of the Resurrection.
Catechetical School of Alexandria
An extremely influential school of theologians and priests in Alexandria, originally founded by Mark the Apostle but destroyed in 381 CE after riots following the Council of Constantinople.
Saint Peter's Basilica
The traditional seat of the Bishop of Rome, commissioned in 318 CE by the Roman Emperor Constantine and originally finished in 322 CE.
Canterbury Cathedral
One of the oldest Christian churches in England, founded in 597 CE.
Cathedral Church of Saint Peter
Cathedral church, dedicated to Saint Peter, built on a site occupied by Churches since the 4th Century.
Santiago de Compostela Cathedral
Grand Cathedral built on the site of the tomb of Saint James the Great.
Basilica of Saints Nazarius and Celsus
Temple of the Poor of Lombardy
Temple of the Poor of Lyon
Abbey of Saint Mary de Pratis
Basilica of Saint John
A Basilica built on the burial site of Saint John the Apostle by Emperor Justinian I. Originally completed in 565 CE.
Helandaris Monastery
A monastery on the slopes of the holy Mount Athos.
Dievas's Sanctuary
A sanctuary dedicated to Dievas, holy to the Baltic faiths.
Temple of Gabija
A temple dedicated to the Baltic fire Goddess Gabija. Holy to the Baltic faiths. An eternal bonfire burns in its center.
Shrine at Laima's Grove
A shrine within a grove dedicated to the Baltic Goddess Laima. Holy to the Baltic faiths.
Shrine in Perkunas's Forest
A shrine, deep in the forest dedicated to the Baltic God Perkunas. Holy to the Baltic faiths.
Romuva Temple
A temple, holy to the Baltic faiths, dedicated to Patrimpas, Perkunas, and Patulas
The Bryn Gwyn Stones
A circle of eight standing stones, aligned to the Summer and Winter solstices, holy to the Celtic faiths.
The Callanish Stones
A cruciform pattern of standing stones, holy to the Celtic faiths.
The Carnac Stones
A dense collection of standing stones, holy to the Celtic faiths.
Lia Fáil
The Stone of Destiny. Coronation stone of the High Kings of Ireland and holy to the Celtic faiths.
Stonehenge
A ring of standing stones, built in time immemorial and holy to the Celtic faiths.
Irminsul

A shrine at the base of a large tree holy to the Nordic and Continental Germanic faiths. Said to be the Earthly representation of the World Tree upon which the Allfather sacrificed himself to himself.
Shrine at Nerthus's Glade
A shrine said to be inhabited by the Germanic Goddess Nerthus. The site is holy to the Continental Germanic faiths.
Shrine at Nehalennia's Grove
A shrine within the holy grove of Nehalennia said to be home to the Goddess. The site is holy to the Continental Germanic faiths.
Thunær's Oak
A shrine at the base of large tree holy to the Continental Germanic faiths. Said to be the home to the God Thunær
Wayland's Smithy
A stone structure said to be the home and forge of the Continental Germanic God Wayland. Travelers who leave offerings here are said to have their horses shod by an invisible smith.
Frey's Temple
A large temple said to have been founded and once inhabited by the Nordic God Frey. As such it is holy to the Nordic faiths.
Shrine at Njörðr's Glade
A shrine said to be inhabited by the Norse God Njörðr. The site is holy to the Nordic faiths.
Thor's Temple
A large temple, said to have been founded and once inhabited by the Nordic God Thor. As such it is holy to the Nordic faiths.
Shrine at Goðafoss Waterfall

A shrine overlooking the Goðafoss Waterfall, where Þorgeir Ljósvetningagoði threw his idols of the Old Gods upon declaring that Iceland would convert to Christianity while still allowing the worship of the Nordic Gods in secret. This place is now holy to the Nordic faiths.
